bibl.title: Lewis Johnson v. Defendant. Witness Testimony, Robert Tate.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21: US District Court, Western Division of Washington, Seatle

div1.p: ROBERT TATE 821 Campbell Ave. called as a witness, being first sworn, testified as follows:
QUESTIONS by MR KENNEDY:
50 Q. What is your occupation? A Porter and waiter.
51 Q. Do you know Lewis Johnston? A Yes sir
52 Q. How long have you known him? A. A little over a year
53 Q. Do you remember the 4th of June? A. I really don't know the date, but I remember Friday, Saturday morning. I paid no attention to the date.
54 Q. How many Saturdays ago? A. Pardon me, just a minute. I paid no attention to the date.
55 Q. But how many weeks ago? Would you know how many Saturdays have intervened since then? A. The Saturday before last.
56 Q. That would be the 5th. Did you see Johnston on that date A. He came to the house where I live between four and five in the morning
57 Q. Where do you live? A. 821 Campbell Avenue
58 Q. And alone? A. Yes sir I room a lone but there are other people in the house.

59 Q. Now I want you to tell us in your own words, please, with out any prompting what conversation you had with Johnston in connection with this charge? A. He came to the house between 4 and 5 in the morning - I didn't notice the time so much either - but he came there really early in the morning and knocked at the back door, and the lady of the house opened the door and he asked her for "Bob"

60 Q. You are "Bob", eh? A. Yes. He said "I want to see him on some very important business" So she opened the door and he came in, and he was in the kitchen when I came down, and she called to me that Mr Johnston wanted to see me on some very important business; and I went out there and he had a bottle of Gin and several packages of cigarettes; and he said he came to give me the time of my life, that he was going to the States; and I sat down and had a drink; and he said he had come into some money.
We sat there and drank awhile and he said "Bob will you go down-town today and get my shoes fixed and buy me some underwear" and I said "yes"; and he said "I will go and catch Garnet before he goes to bed. I have get to get some money" he said "I wll have to go now because he is up at the club all night" and he said "will you come with me" and I said "yes" so we left the house and went over to the Eagle Rooms on Keefer Street, and he telephoned from there; and when he gets back to the telephone he finds he hasn't any nickel, and he comes and calls me and I gave him a nickel.

61. Q. To use for the telephone? A. Yes and I heard him say "bring me a hundred dollars" so when he comes out he said "By George" he said "I ought to have asked for $130. He has got three small ten dollar bills too" He come out and goes down towards Garnett's club; being early in the morning the front door is closed, and he went round the back way. I went round the front on the corner of Gore and Keefer, and took a notion to steal down that way, and as I did I saw him and Garnett come from the back of the club to the barber's shop and Garnett kneeled down in front of the safe and opened it and handed Johnston something.

62. Q. Something in the nature of bills, A. I don't know; he went in there and handed him something, and he came out, and met me on Gore Avenue; and as we walked up Harris street he shewed me two new fifty dollar bills of the Bank of Commerce. I remember looking at the numbers and saying"those are new bills." 0156 something

63. Q. And some other numbers? A. Yes those were the first numbers 0156 something, because I remember repeating the numbers; and then I said to him "new money, whe did you get that money Johnston?" and he said "do you know I was in the Government service in the United States Army?" and I said "yes" and he said "this is the service money from the Phillipine Islands" and I have plenty more" and I said "alright"; and he goes back
out to the house and starts drinking gin again; and by this time he produced a blue paper and said there was five dollar's worth of cocaine in it, and he started using this cocaine. Well he told several different stories, but never anything about stealing the money; about the Phillipines and service; and using that cocaine.

64. Q. What other story did he tell except that he got it at the Phillipines? A. I haven't got to that. So we just thought that was cocaine illusion and didn't pay any attention to it. We kind of just laughed at everything he said

65. Q. Who is "we" A. The lady of the house. So in the meantime Sunday, that was Saturday, Saturday I goes out, I guess up town, he asked me to get him some underwear and get his shoes soled and heeled, and he hands me a fifty dollar bill; and I went up and got two suits of underwear and got his shoes fixed and came back to the house and gave him his change. I started up-town again for something for myself, and he said "by the way I want a Jaeger shirt. Will you get it for me?" And I said "yes" and he gave me the other fifty dollar bill. I said you have got change in your pocket John, why don't you give me that change?" and he said "I am going to the States and since this War is on these large bills are hard to change." So I took the bill and bought him a Jaeger shirt; and I went back to the house and gave him the change. And so he kept on drinking all that evening, and he goes up town and came back along early Sunday morning; and he had been drinking pretty hard; he said he had been to a dance or some- thing and given everybody a good time.And this was the time he commenced telling us about stealing the money. He was drinking pretty hard and still using the cocaine which was pretty nearly all gone, and I got after him about stealing the money

66 Q. He mentioned about stealing the money? A. No we asked him about where he got it; and the lady and I talked about it, we said "it looks suspicious this fellow spending a hundred
dollars so freely" and I took up a newspaper and I said "does he act as if he killed anybody?"

67. Q. Who did you say that to? A. The lady of the house: She said "I don't think so; he seems nervous about something, but the chances are it is the dope he is using" and I took up a paper and said "man found with his head smashed in" What do you think of that" and looked at him, and he didn't shew any signs of nervousness. And I looked at her and I laid the paper down and paid no attention to it; and I said "he hasn't killed anybody because he couldn't be that calm about it" Then he sat down and told us that he had gone into the Main Hotel back to urinate and eeen a man lying there with his feet in the water, seemingly drunk

68. Q. Lying in the water? A. His feet were in the water of the Urinal, and he reached down and struck his right-hand pocket and felt a purse in there. He put his life hands under his arms and as he done so he struck the purse in his pocket; and he said he had five cents in his pocket, and walked out to the bar and got a glass of beer.

69. Q. Who had five cents? A. Johnston. And he went up to room 29 of the Lyle Rooms and hid the money in there, and he looked and saw there were fifty dollar bills, and there was a little noise in the hall, and he started to throw the purse out of the window, but as the noise passed he looked again and saw a hundred dollar bill, and he looked and saw another one and he counted seventeen one hundred dollar bills, two fifties and three ten dollar bils I said you "you have told many a story about that Johnston; the next thing you know you will be killing some "ermans" He said that will be alright. I have got the money anyway" He said "I went and got Garnett and told him I wanted him to do me a little favor, that I had made a little money and that I would give him seventyfive or a hundred dollars if he could get it changed up into gold for me. I don't want anything but gold." I didn't pay much attention. I didn't believe what he was saying. I knew some-
thing was wrong somewhere but I didn't know what it was, and didn't believe what he was saying. That was after dinner Sunday afternoon. So he goes out again Sunday evening; and in the morning he comes in - that is when he handed us a drink. I was sitting on the side of the bed and he had a bottle with about that much whiskey in it; and he gave us all some, and I don't remember seeing Johnston any more till I saw him over in Seattle.
70 Q. How did you come to meet him in Seattle? A. I met him in a saloon.
71 Q. Where? A. On the corner of King and 16th
72 Q. That is in Seattle? A. Yes
73 Q. How did you come tobe over there? A. I went over with the officers to locate him.
74 Q. Had you known Johnston for some time before that? A. John- ston about a year and a half
75 Q. Did you ever know him to do anything, or have any money? A. No sir
76 Q. Well did you know him not to do anything? That is did you know he didn't work? A. I don't know anything he done. I don't know of any work he did.
77 Q. Do you know if he had any money or not? A. He never had any. He had stayed at the house the biggest part of the Winter with me and didn't pay any board or room.
78 Q. At your place. A. Yes rooming with me
79 Q. What reason did he give for not paying any board or room A. He didn't have any money
80 Q. That is what made you suspicious I presume in the first place when he came into all this money? A. Yes
81 Q. Had he ever told you anything before about being in the Phillipines or soldiering of any kind? A. Oh he told of several people he killed in the line of duty
82 Q. Hadn't told you of any sum of money that was coming to him? A. No

83 Q. Did you happen to ask him what happened to all the rest of
the money. All you had seen, you remember, was two fifty dollar bills. Allo told me that Garnett had it when I asked him about it. I asked him where it ws, and he said "Garnett has it and will have changed it for me"

84 Q. Did Johnston say anything about being satisfied with Garnett at all? A. He sent me out - he asked if I knew a truthful man, and I said "I don't know of anybody but a messenger boy"; and he said "I will give him five dollars" - he was in the shoe-shop at this time

85 Q. Johnston was where - in the shoe-shop? A. Yes. He said he would give a man five dollar if he would find out if Garnett was in a house on Alexander street, and if he was to trail him until that afternoon and if he went near a train or boat just to get into a taxi and go immediately and let him know.
86 Q. When was it Johnstone told you that? A. That was between the....
87 Q. Was that Saturday or Sunday? A. Saturday

88 Q. What is his name? A. Curly. That is the only name I know him by, down at that Home Messenger Office. I left out a part about Garnett. I sent for Garnett after I seen it in the paper on Monday Night. That is when I believed that he stole this money when I saw in the paper about that eighteen hundred dollars in the Main Hotel, on Monday night
90 Q. Of course Johnston had gone then? A. Yes
91 Q. Do you know what happened to the pocket-book? A. He tore it up

92 Q. Who said so? A. Johnston said so, I asked him what he done with it. I said there might have been valuable papers in that pocket-book, that might be worth a thousand dollars to a man, and he said "I tore it and threw it away"
93 Q. Did he describe the pocket-book at all to you? NO sir

94 Q. I will show you a photograph which I shall put in as Exhibit
"A" Do you recognise that photograph? A. That is Johnston
95. Q. This is a photography of Lewis Johnston? A. Yes
PHOTOGRAPH produced as Exhibit "A"
